values.alignmentText: Havana's biosphere reserves and reefs are pristine, but aging infrastructure and fuel shortages cause periodic pollution spikes.
Cuba faces stronger hurricanes and sea-level rise; coastal homes are at risk, so evacuation planning and resilient housing are essential for this family.
Cuba has a tropical climate with hot, humid weather most of the year and a June–November hurricane season. Winters are milder, but humidity stays high.
Outside Havana, air quality is mixed due to aging diesel buses and classic cars that leave city corridors hazy. Indoor air filters help protect our sensitive family members.
Hurricanes and coastal flooding are regular risks in Cuba; expect periodic disruptions, but recovery systems mitigate impact.
Havana spring 25–31 C (77–88 F) with rising humidity; May rains begin—warm, not ideal for mild-year-round prefs; plan shade and hydration.
Havana, Cuba summers run ~31–33 C (88–91 F) with high humidity; frequent storms and hurricane season (Jun–Nov) affect outdoor time.
Fall in Havana stays warm (27-31 C); Sep-Oct hurricane risk; by Nov it eases to milder days, matching a mild-year-round preference.
Havana winters are mild; days ~25–27 C (77–81 F), nights ~18–20 C (64–68 F); no freezing risk.
Beaches around Varadero/Havana offer clean sand and solid amenities; water quality monitoring is transparent; expect seasonal crowds near hubs.
Sea water near Cuba stays about 24-28 C most months, enabling long swims without wetsuits. For hotter days, light rash guards help the kids stay comfortable.
Cuba has lush coasts and valleys; family-friendly nature with easy tours (Varadero, Viñales, Zapata) and distinct seasonal beauty.
Minimum wage in Cuba remains very low; likely insufficient for a four-person family without remittances or multi-job income, even with subsidies.
In Cuba, software pay is modest with limited private demand; broadband is constrained, so remote work for international firms or grants is often needed.
Cuba's .NET market is small; few local roles exist and remote gigs are irregular, hampered by bandwidth limits and modest wages.
Cuba's Ruby market is virtually non-existent; startups are scarce and remote options are limited. Relocation or remote work from abroad may be necessary.
In Cuba, sponsorship for non-Cubans is rare; few employers sponsor and approvals are slow with uncertain timelines.
Cuba's economy shows persistent weakness amid sanctions and shortages. Wages and services can be unstable, impacting family planning.
In Cuba, home broadband is scarce and Wi-Fi hotspots require prepaid cards. Outages disrupt remote meetings, so remote work remains limited.
In Cuba, family time is central and evenings balance life, but power outages and ration lines cut downtime; broadband limits remote-work flexibility.
Cuban workweeks average around 40-45 hours; aligns with level 7 (40-hour norm with occasional 42-45).
Cuba provides about 14 paid vacation days; in the 10–14 day band; full use is feasible but modest vs many countries.
Cuba typically offers around 20-24 paid days per year. Holidays and local schedules can trim downtime, impacting long trips for this family.
Pace varies by Cuban neighborhood; slower life outside Havana fits your family. Expect bureaucratic delays in urban cores like Havana.
In Cuba, schools often end early and aftercare is limited; families rely on flexible remote days or neighbor/paid care.
In Cuba, weekends for a family of four hinge on parks, beaches, and community events. Expect more planning and modest budgets due to fewer hourly options.
Cuba offers strong family networks, universal healthcare and education, plus safe parks and kid-friendly spaces within tight-knit communities.
Cuba offers limited polyamory acceptance; no legal recognition, and families may face social stigma.
Cuba's centralized system and school structure drive traditional parenting norms; families face stronger guidance from teachers and relatives.
Cities in Cuba welcome kids with public spaces and safety. Healthcare is strong, but aging infrastructure and English limits can complicate daily life.

Universal, state-run pre-K for 5-year-olds in Cuba; under-5 childcare exists, but bilingual options and hours are limited.

Vibrant Cuban music, dance, architecture, and contemporary art offer frequent surprises that keep our family engaged.

Cuba provides school-based sex education and universal health care; Havana leans liberal, while rural areas remain more conservative.

In Cuba (Havana), the self-view is resilient and solidarity-driven, but state messaging and restricted liberties temper pride.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Caribbean neighbors value Cuba's vibrant culture, but political isolation fuels skepticism; for a US-origin family, travel and language access matter.
Nightlife exists in specific Cuban districts. Plan with sitters and transport, as family-friendly late options are limited.

In Cuba, mainstream hobbies lean to baseball and music; gaming/board games are niche, so expect limited local groups or need to travel for meetups.

Havana's music scene is vibrant with live venues and street performances; many family-friendly options and accessible transit exist in Cuba.

Cuba's single-party system restricts political participation. Civil liberties are limited and reforms occur slowly.
Secular state in Cuba; religion has limited policy influence. Some religious references exist in law, but minority rights remain protected.
Cuba: worker protections exist on paper, but independent unions are restricted and activism is discouraged; enforcement is uneven.

Cuba's economy remains state-led with limited market mechanisms; private enterprise exists, but reforms proceed slowly.

Safe overall; Cuba has low violent crime, but petty theft affects tourist areas like Havana/Varadero. Stay vigilant and avoid poorly lit zones after dark.

In Cuba, power and internet can be intermittent; most payments are cash-based, and broadband is unreliable for steady remote work.

In Cuba, heat and humidity limit outdoor days. Only short shoulder periods feel comfortable.
In Cuba, universal healthcare and subsidized essentials help cover basics. Housing options can be limited with long waits.
Quality of life in Cuba for a middle-income family depends on steady remote work; housing is affordable but services can be uneven.

In Cuba, immigrants face tight government controls, slower bureaucracy, and limited English; newcomers should expect a defensive climate.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: Cuba lacks dedicated PMM (Games) curricula; few programs in Havana/La Habana, grads need mentoring or study abroad.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: Cuba has limited local continuing education for games product marketing; mainly online resources and rare remote events; local meetups are scarce.
Cuba PMM (Games) hiring: local talent pools are shallow; expect 4-6 month cycles; plan for remote/global searches.
